sourceDesc.p: Select transcriptions of witness statements at the coroner's inquest, to the police and district attorney's office are drawn from the remarkable work done by Bruce Long and other parties as part of the Taylorology website.
For more information, see Taylorology: http://taylorology.com/

head.title: Witness Statement Provided by [NAME]
head.orgName: [FOR WHOM THE STATEMENT WAS GIVEN (POLICE, CORONER, DA)]

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: During the time in the east there, when he (Taylor) was directing her (Mary), did you observe any awakening of a friendship or love between the two of them?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: When did you first see that, or did you at all?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I never did know it, Mr. Keyes, until Mr. Mott told me of the letters that had been found in Taylor's drawer that absolutely is convincing that there had been something there.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: You mean after he was killed?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Yes, and Mr Eyton told me also after Mr. Taylor was killed that he knew that, that he knew for a long time that Mary and Mr. Taylor had been intimate, and I said then "Mr. Eyton you should have told me"

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: During that time, Mrs. Shelby (referring to latter part of 1919 and early part of 1920), was Mary going around with Taylor to your knowledge at all?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Why no, and Mr. Taylor was the most perfectly poised man, such a proper man. He would take Mary out to dinner and he would invariably invite me and my mother to go to dinner with them.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did you make any objections?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Not the least in the world.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Were you friendly with him?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Oh, yes. **

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Do you remember anyone in particular with whom she was associating at that time?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: It wasn't men. Men hadn't begun to give me any trouble at that time. It was women.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Who was that?

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Taylor's name never entered into the discussion then?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No. I always felt that, when Mary was out with Mr. Taylor she was under a good influence. **

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did you ever have any words with Mr. Taylor over Mary?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Never a word, never the slightest word. (Speaking of the time Mrs. Shelby went to Taylor's home at 2 a.m. looking for Mary)

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did this secretary of yours, Miss Whitney, go in the house with you?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, I know she didn't because there was nobody in the room but Mr. Taylor and me. She stayed in the car.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did you have any weapon with you at that time?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Good lord, no.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: You are sure you didn't have a revolver with you?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, Mr. Keyes.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Well, you owned a revolver at that time?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No. If I owned a revolver at that time, I don't know where it was. It was thrown away.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: What date was it when you were at Mr. Taylor's home that you were telling about?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I think I could almost fix that date, Mr. Keyes, referring to a certain little book, you know. Because I was reading Mary's diary and she goes on to say in this diary that she and I had some little words that evening, you see, and she has written it very cleverly, about the small girl going out in a huff, etc., and she adds that mother was right. ** And I think the date of that happening is right in her diary.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did you ever make a threat to kill Mr. Taylor?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, Mr. Keyes. I never had any reason or desire to kill Mr. Taylor.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: And you are positive, are you, Mrs. Shelby, that you never at any time threatened Mr. Taylor?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Certainly not, I had no reason. I never threatened to shoot Mr. Taylor. I don't think I ever threatened to shoot any man.

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: To shoot him? No, because I had no reason. I had no provocation. I never had a quarrel with Mr. Taylor in my life.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: You spoke of having thrown a gun away?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, my mother did that.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: That was your gun?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: The gun was given to me in Santa Barbara by Harry Eaves, who has a jewelry shop up there - a very short little pistol - a little automatic - ** and he said to me, "I have got two and you ought to have one."

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Where did you say you shot it once?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I got a friend of mine to take me out in Santa Barbara, just off the road, and we shot it into a bank and I shot it once.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did you ever do any target practice with it?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Yes, that one time. It was enough for me. The thing was too short. I can shoot a long pistol. I wouldn't mind shooting a shot gun. **

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Well, Mrs. Shelby, Mary shot that pistol off one time, didn't she?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Yes, she shot it off twice.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Was that the "suicide"?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: That's the "suicide". (re supposed suicide) "Well, we were living at 56 Fremont Place. ** I remember the secretary was there that night, Miss Whitney. ** She (Mary) rushed up the steps crying "I am going to end it all. I am going to end it all." ** Then Charlotte (Miss Whitney) said to me, "Mes. Shelby, oh, Mrs. Shelby, there's a pistol in your closet." ** But she ran up the stairs and ran in my room and closed the door.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Did she look the door?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: Oh, locked the door, and the first thing we knew - bang. ** and a second more and - bang - the second shot. ** The chauffeur (Chauncey Eaton) appeared, and the night watchman (?), and I said, "Break in the door". The two men rushed against the door, the door fell in, and there lay Mary on my bedroom floor. ** They picked her up so tenderly, and Chauncey turned her over and he said, "Why, Mrs. Shelby, there is no blood on her." ** By that time the secretary had faded out of the picture in a faint ** and she (Mrs. Shelby's mother, Mrs. Miles) said,"Why no, she is not shot; stand her up, Chauncey." ** Then she (Mary) looked at us and said, "I thought I would give you all a jolt."

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: ** was there anything said about Taylor in that? Did he have anything to do with that quarrel?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, I don't think he had anything to do with that ** I may have asked her if she had been out with Mr. Taylor.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: But there was no quarrel about Mr. Taylor?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: It seems to me she mentioned Taylor's name. I don't remember now, or what. **

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: Then the report that I got that you have been practicing some revolver shooting - is there anything to that?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I told you I shot it once. I know a man who will verify it - Mr. Stockdale.

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: No other pistol at any other time?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: No, I am afraid of pistols. **

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: What did your mother do with your pistol after Mary pulled this stunt?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: That was all there was to it. Of course, we found Charlotte Whitney in a faint on the floor and we had to revive her. ** And Chauncey was trying to find out where the bullets went, and we discovered one bullet had been shot into my closet, and we found that, and another one went up in the ceiling of the closet. I remember mother taking the pistol. She said, "Here, give me that. That's enough of pistols lying around."

sp.speaker: POLICE:
sp.ab: What did she do with it?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I never saw it again. I think I asked her once or twice what she did with it, and she said,"It's out. It's put away."

sp.speaker: MRS. SHELBY:
sp.ab: I had an engagement with a man the next morning (2-2-22) at 9 o'clock. *** This man was a client of a friend of my daughter's, Mr. Albert Reiner. *** I also had been talking to a man about buying an Aeolian Organ, and he stopped 1n that morning And while these two men were in the room, the telephone rang. It was then a little after 9, and Mr. Carl Stockdale called me up. He had gone to the studio to work and had learned of the death of William Desmond Taylor. Naturally, knowing that he directed Mary, he called me up and told me that William Desmond Taylor bad been found dead that morning.
Just what did he tell you?

He said, "Mrs. Shelby, I just wanted to call you up and tell you. I am at the studio. William Desmond Taylor was found dead this morning." "Oh," I said, "that's terrible." That's all he knew. ** I turned to these gentlemen and said, "Oh, my, it's terrible. A man who directed my daughter, a very charming gentleman, was found dead this morning." ** In a few minutes the telephone rang again. ** This time Miss Berger said, "William Desmond Taylor was murdered this morning. He was shot." I said, "Oh, my, this is terrible; the man was murdered? Was shot?" So we discussed that and the organ man knew I was waiting to go out with Mr. Rice so ** Mr. Rice and I got in his car ** and I said, "Mr. Rice, do you mind if I stop at my house and tell my people?" ** and it seems to me that on the way crossing Vermont I met my mother coming over in a car with the chauffeur and I just waved to her to turn around and come on back with us. I remember that distinctly. ** I was in a great hurry because Mr. Rice was waiting for me in front, and I remember the chauffeur had parked my blue Packard in the driveway, and something was said about Mary wanted the car. Chauncey had gone to get Mary's car. However, I went upstairs in a great hurry, and I said, "Oh, Julia, dear, Mr. Taylor was murdered last night." She said, "Oh, it isn't possible. I can't believe it. It isn't true." I said, "Oh, yes, it is. Miss Berger told me so." **
Did Mr. Woolwine ever try to take your statement?
No, he never asked me a thing, Mr. Keyes. Nobody ever questioned me.
Tell Mr. Keyes exactly now, that part of the conversation with Chauncey?

I said, "Chauncey, what did you tell them?" He said, "I told them that you called me up very early that morning, about half past seven, and my wife said you went over there without breakfast; that you wanted to go over to the Hobart house." I said, "The morning of the Taylor murder?" He said, "Yes." I said, "Why, I couldn't have known until after 9 o'clock." He said that he drove me over that morning and said that I was at the window with the papers. I said, "How could that be; besides there wasn't any papers that morning." "No," he said, "that's what they told me down at the office, that there wasn't any papers that early." I said, "Well, that's nothing, it is just a lapse of memory, it is of no consequence." And finally he saw he was in the wrong. I explained to him that Mr. Rice had driven me over.
Now explain that Monte Blue proposition.

(Mrs. Shelby tells about some night when Mary had failed to come home, and they had looked for her until about 2:30 a.m. and finally located her car in front of Charlotte Whitney's house) So Margaret and I rushed in and went up the steps hurriedly and opened the door and came upon Mary and Monte Blue on the couch. The door opened right into the front room. This Monte Blue started to run out into the kitchen and out the back door.
You mean that they were in a compromising position?

Yes. I was about the maddest woman that could ever be. I grabbed this halfbreed Indian by his shirt tail and I said, "Come right back in this room. I have something very forceful to say to you. Come back here."
That time she went out with Marshall Neilan, after the murder; wasn't that about two nights afterward?
Yes.
Immediately afterwards, wasn't it?
It was.
She tried to kill you, you say?
Yes. ** Oh, Mary said around the house freely, "Oh, Mrs. Shelby killed Taylor". Not only once but many times. She was always saying that.
